question.title: How to suppress the "Deprecated member 'A' is still used" warning using a @SuppressWarning annotation in Java?
question.body:
What value should I use to suppress this warning in IntellijIdea?

I have searched through JSL documentation, multiple sites and similar questions on StackOverFlow - nothing changed. I understand that I can use "all" but I don't wanna do it.

@SuppressWarnings(value = {"deprecation"})
@Deprecated
class A {
}

public class Main {
    @SuppressWarnings(value = {"deprecation"})
    public static void main(String[] arguments) {
        A a = new A();
    }
}

I want to suppress warning, which appears exactly in class A. Could u help me?

answers.body:
When you use IDEA you can use that to create the suppression annotation: Rightclick the yellow marked part (in your example they type A from the assignment statement A a = new A()), select Show Context Actions (the "lightbulb"), select `Inspection 'Deprecated API usage' options and pick Suppress for statement.

This will generate the right annotation in the correct place and look like that:

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") A a = new A();
    }
}

While the @SuppressWarnings on main suppresses the "deprecated API usage" inspection, the inspection that appears on the line class A { is a different inspection, called "deprecated member is still used".

You can see both of them from the inspection settings:

The difference is that "deprecated API usage" appears at the use site of deprecated things, whereas "deprecated member is still used" appears at the declarations of deprecated things that are still being used elsewhere in your code.

Note that due to performance reasons, IntelliJ only tries to check "deprecated member is still used" if the name of that deprecated thing is rarely used in your project. This is unlike "deprecated API usage".

You can disable "deprecated member is still used" globally in the inspection settings (this will not affect "deprecated API usage"), or you can disable it just for A:

@SuppressWarnings("DeprecatedIsStillUsed")
@Deprecated
class A {
}

question_comments.body: You probably can just add @Deprecated to the main method. It's generally okay for deprecated methods to use deprecated classes and methods. No @SuppressWarnings annotations needed.
best way is not to use it anymore. The warnings will disappear quite fast. Are you planning to use it until after it has been deleted?
Why do you mark it as deprecated and then suppress the warning?

by @RobSpoor. You need to suppress the warning in class Main, not class A. Preferably, only suppress the warning in the main method. That won't work if A is in a different package and therefore imported; the only way to get rid off deprecated import warnings is to suppress warnings for the entire class.

79741155.body: @pityamskoy See cyberbrain's answer. You basically do the same thing on class A instead of A a = new A();. If you select "Suppress for class", a @SuppressWarnings will be automatically generated. You should not type the warning name manually. See also: jetbrains.com/help/idea/…
Could you give me a resource where all information about values for @SuppressWarnings is stored?
Where have you found such information about @SuppressWarnings("DeprecatedIsStillUsed"). It is very applicable to know how to deal with this sort of problems

79741064.body: That's not what I meant. OP has done the same thing you have. The same string ("deprecation") that covers every bit of scope that your final conclusion also covers. Hence, you haven't given them anything useful. What you provided they already have.

If you want to suppress the warning in general (just this warning, but for the widest scope) you can disable it in the inspection settings, but I didn't think that the OP wants to do that (and I don't want to encourage somebody to do that)

Unless IntelliJ is bugged, what you end up with is no different from what OP has. Shifting the warning from method body to vardecl decreases its scope; it doesn't increase it. Either something else is going wrong, or OP did not actually try the code they put in their own question, or IntelliJ has a bug.
